details.title: A methodology for predicting service life and design of reliability experiments

authors.affiliation: United Technol. Res. Center, East Hartford, CT, USA

p: Payman Sadegh (M'99) received a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering in 1993, and a Ph.D. in Mathematical Statistics and Operations Research in 1997, both from Denmark Technical University. He received a Master of Business Administration from Indiana University Kelley School of Business in 2004.

He has been with the United Technologies Research Center since 2001 where he has worked on a variety of projects in diagnostics & prognostic health management, economic optimization, and reliability modeling. His previous work experience includes a postdoc at the Department of Computer Science of the Johns Hopkins University where he developed algorithms for image-based planning of optimal treatment delivery, and senior associate at PriceWaterhouseCoopers Applied Decision Analysis. He has published in the areas of design of experiments for dynamic system identification, high-dimensional optimization via application of simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation, and optimal treatment delivery.
Dr. Sadegh has been a referee for IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON AUTOMATIC CONTROL.

authors.name: P. Sadegh

authors.affiliation: United Technol. Res. Center, East Hartford, CT, USA

p: Adrian Thompson received the B. Sc. degree in Chemical & Process Engineering at the University of the West Indies in 1992, and the Ph.D. degree in Process Systems Control from the University of Toronto in 2004. He is currently a member of the IEEE.

He worked as a Process Development Engineer at Alcan Jamaica Company, Kirkvine, Jamaica from 1992 to 1997. In 2002, he joined the United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT, as a Staff Research Engineer, where he now works on projects in control theory, embedded systems, wireless sensor networks, system reliability, diagnostics, and prognostic health management. He has previously published in the areas of stochastic dynamic programming, and stochastic optimal control theory.
Dr. Thompson is a also member of the AICHE; and has refereed technical papers for the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CONTROL SYSTEM TECHNOLOGY, and the American Control Conference.

authors.name: T. Sienel

details.abstract: This paper summarizes a methodology for reliability prediction of new products where field data are sparse, and the allowed number & length of experiments are limited. The methodology relies on estimating a set where the unknown parameters are most likely to be found, calculation of an upper bound for the reliability metric of interest conditioned that the parameters reside in the estimated set, and tightening the bounds via design of experiments. Models of failure propagation, failure acceleration, system operations, and time/cycle to failure at various levels of fidelity & expert elicited information may be incorporated to enhance the accuracy of the predictions. The application of the model is illustrated through numerical studies.

references.title: Using accelerated tests to predict service life in highly-variable environments

context.text: Accelerated life testing (ALT) has been recognized as a methodology that can usefully predict service life [1], [2].

references.text: W. Q. Meeker, L. A. Escobar, V. Chan, "Using accelerated tests to predict service life in highly-variable environments", Proceedings of International Statistical Institute, 1999.

references.title: A new approach to system reliability

context.text: Another important class of problems in the area of system reliability deals with calculating system-reliability based on the structure of the system [8].

links.abstract: Calculating system-reliability via the knowledge of structure function is not new. However, such attempts have had to compromise with the increasing complexity of a system. This paper overcomes this problem through a new representation of the structure function, and demonstrates that the well-known systems considered in the state-of-art follow this new representation. With this new representation, the important reliability calculations, such as Birnbaum reliability-importance, become simple. The...

references.text: G. Chaudhuri, K. Hu, N. Afshar, "A new approach to system reliability", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 50, no. 1, Mar. 2001.

references.title: Order Statistics, Wiley Series in Probability and Mathematical Statistics

context.text: The joint probability density function \$L_{i,pdf}\$ of any instantiation \$\widetilde{\tau }_{eq,i}^{(1)},\ldots,\widetilde{\tau}_{eq,i}^{(n_{i})}\$ of \$\widetilde{\rm T}_{eq, i}^{(1)},\ldots,\widetilde{\rm T}_{eq,i}^{(n_{i})}\$ is then given by \$L_{i,pdf} = n_{i}!\pi_{i}(\widetilde{\tau}_{eq,i}^{(1)})\ldots\pi_{i}(\widetilde{\tau}_{eq,i}^{(n_{i})})\$ if \$\widetilde{\tau}_{eq,i}^{(1)}\leq\ldots\leq\widetilde{\tau}_{eq,i}^{(n_{i})}\$, and zero otherwise [10].

references.text: H. A. David, Order Statistics Wiley Series in Probability and Mathematical Statistics, 1981.

references.title: Fault tree analysis, methods, and applications&#821a review

context.text: Fault trees relate occurrence of the top-level (system) failure as a logical function of occurrence of smaller failure modes that usually happen at component or smaller part divisions [11].

links.abstract: This paper reviews and classifies fault-tree analysis methods developed since 1960 for system safety and reliability. Fault-tree analysis is a useful analytic tool for the reliability and safety of complex systems. The literature on fault-tree analysis is, for the most part, scattered through conference proceedings and company reports. We have classified the literature according to system definition, fault-tree construction, qualitative evaluation, quantitative evaluation, and available computer...

references.text: W. S. Lee, D. L. Grosh, F. A. Tillman, C. H. Lie, "Fault tree analysis methods and applications̵a review", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 34, no. 3, pp. 194-203, 1985.
